tit.e: Kurokuwa (a construction worker; written as 黒鍬 in kanji (Chinese characters))
tit.cmt: 下に「畔鍬とも表記する」の記述があるので、「黒鍬」の漢字表記を追記しました。
説明は直後の文章に付け、タイトルからは削除しました。
統一リストに従って、説明の補足を戻しました。

sen.j: 黒鍬（くろくわ）は戦国時代 (日本)や江戸時代に土木作業を行う者達を指す。
sen.e: Kurokuwa (a construction worker) refers to people engaged in civil engineering in the Sengoku period (period of warring states) and Edo period.
Kurokuwa (黒鍬) (a construction worker) refers to people engaged in civil engineering in the Sengoku period (period of warring states) and Edo period.
sen.cmt: 黒鍬の漢字表記はこの文章に補いました。
sen.e: Kurokuwa (黒鍬) (a construction worker) refers to people engaged in civil engineering in the Sengoku period (period of warring states) and Edo period.
It was also written as 畔鍬 in kanji (Chinese characters).
It was also written 畔鍬 in kanji.
sen.cmt: 漢字の説明は不要だと思いますので削除しました。
sen.e: It was also written 畔鍬 in kanji.

sen.j: 語源に当たる黒鍬は通常の鍬より刃が厚くて幅が広く、刃と柄の角度が60～80度に開いている。
sen.e: Kurokuwa (black hoe) which was the origin of a word had a thicker and wider blade than a usual hoe, and a degree of angle between a blade and a shaft was 60 to 80.
Kurokuwa originally means black hoe with a thicker and wider blade than usual hoe, and the degree of angle between blade and shaft is 60 to 80.
sen.cmt: 「語源に当たる」訳を修正しました。文法を修正しました。
sen.e: Kurokuwa originally means black hoe with a thicker and wider blade than usual hoe, and the degree of angle between blade and shaft is 60 to 80.

sen.j: さらに、柄が太く短くできていることで力を加えやすく、打ち下ろした時に深く土に食い込むようにできている鍬の事である。
sen.e: Furthermore, kurokuwa (black hoe) also refers to a hoe whose shaft was thick and short so as to exert a force easily and dig into a ground deeply when banging down.
Furthermore, kurokuwa is a hoe whose shaft is thick and short so as to make is easy to apply force and dig into the ground deeply when banging down.
sen.cmt: 時制を現在に修正しました。「力を加えやすく」の部分の訳を修正しました。
sen.e: Furthermore, kurokuwa is a hoe whose shaft is thick and short so as to make is easy to apply force and dig into the ground deeply when banging down.

sen.j: 戦国大名に仕えた黒鍬は小荷駄隊に属して、陣地や橋などの築造や戦死者の収容・埋葬などを行った。
sen.e: Kurokuwa (a construction worker) attending on daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) in the Sengoku period belonged to konidatai (caravan of men and animals carrying supplies), and engaged in constructing encampments, bridges and so on, and recovering and burying persons killed in war.

Kurokuwa serving daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) in the Sengoku period belonged to konidatai (caravan of men and animals carrying supplies) and engaged in constructing encampments, bridges and so on, and recovering and burying persons killed in war.
sen.cmt: 重複する説明は削除しました。
sen.e: Kurokuwa serving daimyo (Japanese territorial lord) in the Sengoku period belonged to konidatai (caravan of men and animals carrying supplies) and engaged in constructing encampments, bridges and so on, and recovering and burying persons killed in war.

sen.j: 後世の工兵の役割を担っていたと考えられている。
sen.e: It is considered that kurokuwa (a construction worker) played a role as kohei (military engineer) in later periods.
It is considered that kurokuwa played a role corresponding to that of kohei (military engineer) in later periods.
sen.cmt: 不要な説明は削除しました。「後世に登場する工兵と同じ役割」という意味に修正しました。
sen.e: It is considered that kurokuwa played a role corresponding to that of kohei (military engineer) in later periods.

sen.j: 江戸幕府の組織としての黒鍬(組)も三河国松平氏時代からの譜代の黒鍬から構成されており、若年寄支配で小者･中間として江戸城内の修築作業や幕府から出される諸令伝達や草履取り等の雑務に従事した。
sen.e: Kurokuwa (unit of construction workers) as an organization of Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) also consisted of kurokuwa (a construction worker) who had been fudai (hereditary vassals) since the era of Matsudaira clan in Mikawa Province, and was in charge of repairing work in the Edo-jo Castle, transmission of orders issued by the bakufu, miscellaneous affairs such as zoritori (sandal bearer, equivalent to a batman) and so on, as komono (a lower servant) or chugen (a rank below common soldier) under the control of wakadoshiyori (a managerial position in Edo bakufu).
sen.cmt: 若年寄支配で→under the control of wakadoshiyori (a managerial position in the Edo bakufu)[『若年寄の支配を受けて』と解釈しました]
sen.e: Kurokuwa also indicated the unit of kurokuwa (construction workers) which was one of the organizations of Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun,) consisting of kurokuwa who had been fudai (hereditary vassals) since the era of Matsudaira clan of Mikawa Province and were in charge of repairing work in the Edo-jo Castle, transmission of orders issued by the bakufu, miscellaneous affairs such as zoritori (sandal bearer, equivalent to a batman,) and whose status was komono (a lower servant) or chugen (a rank below common soldier) under the control of wakadoshiyori (a managerial position in Edo bakufu).
sen.cmt: 分かりづらい部分の語順を整えました。
sen.e: Kurokuwa also indicated the unit of kurokuwa (construction workers) which was one of the organizations of Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun,) consisting of kurokuwa who had been fudai (hereditary vassals) since the era of Matsudaira clan of Mikawa Province and were in charge of repairing work in the Edo-jo Castle, transmission of orders issued by the bakufu, miscellaneous affairs such as zoritori (sandal bearer, equivalent to a batman,) and whose status was komono (a lower servant) or chugen (a rank below common soldier) under the control of wakadoshiyori (a managerial position in Edo bakufu).

sen.j: 食禄は1人当たり12俵1人扶持が原則で役職に付くと、役高が加算された。
sen.e: Shokuroku (a salary for samurais who worked at Japanese feudal governments) per person was 12 bales (a traditional unit for rice, which is 60 kilograms) of one-man rice stipend, in principle, and when kurokuwa assumed a post, yakudaka (salary paid in accordance with the rank of one's post) was added.

Shokuroku (a salary for samurais who worked at Japanese feudal governments) was 17 bales (a traditional unit for rice, which is 60 kilograms) per person in principle, and when kurokuwa assumed a post, yakudaka (salary paid in accordance with the rank of one's post) was added.
sen.cmt: 文法を修正しました。1人扶持は約5俵で「12俵1人扶持」は17俵のことです。ご参考http://www.viva-edo.com/houroku.html
sen.e: Shokuroku (a salary for samurais who worked at Japanese feudal governments) was 17 bales (a traditional unit for rice, which is 60 kilograms) per person in principle, and when kurokuwa assumed a post, yakudaka (salary paid in accordance with the rank of one's post) was added.

sen.j: 当初は苗字帯刀も許されず、例外的に護身用の脇差だけを持つ事が許されたが、三河譜代の黒鍬については、世襲が許され、後には御家人の最下層格の扱いを受けた。
sen.e: At first, it was not permitted to adopt a surname and wear a pair of swords, and it was only permitted to wear a short sword for self-defense exceptionally, but kurokuwa who was fudai (hereditary vassal) in Mikawa Province was permitted to conduct heredity, and was treated as the lowest rank of Gokenin (shogunal retainers of the Kamakura bakufu) later.

At first, kurokuwa were not permitted to adopt a surname or wear a pair of swords except for a short sword for self-defense, but those kurokuwa of fudai in Mikawa Province were allowed hereditary succession and were treated as the lowest rank of Gokenin (shogunal retainers of the Kamakura bakufu) later.
sen.cmt: 主語をkurokuwaと明記しました。「conduct succession」という用例は見つかりませんでしたので言い回しを修正しました。文法を修正しました。
sen.e: At first, kurokuwa were not permitted to adopt a surname or wear a pair of swords except for a short sword for self-defense, but those kurokuwa of fudai in Mikawa Province were allowed hereditary succession and were treated as the lowest rank of Gokenin (shogunal retainers of the Kamakura bakufu) later.

sen.j: 黒鍬の長である黒鍬頭（くろくわかしら）は、役高100俵の待遇を受けた。
sen.e: Kurokuwakashira, a head of kurokuwa (unit of construction workers in this case), received a treatment of yakudaka (salary paid in accordance with the rank of one's post) of 100 bales.
Kurokuwakashira, the head of kurokuwa (unit,) received yakudaka of 100 bales.
sen.cmt: 不要な説明を削除しました。
sen.e: Kurokuwakashira, the head of kurokuwa (unit,) received yakudaka of 100 bales.

sen.j: 定員は天和 (日本)年間の定制は200名であったが、享保年間には430名となり、幕末には470名にまで増員された。
sen.e: The fixed number was specified as 200 in the Tenna era, but increased to 430 in the Kyoho era, then to 470 at the end of Edo period.
The number of kurokuwa was fixed to 200 in the Tenna era, but increased to 430 in the Kyoho era, then to 470 at the end of Edo period.
sen.cmt: 自然な言い回しに修正しました。
sen.e: The number of kurokuwa was fixed to 200 in the Tenna era, but increased to 430 in the Kyoho era, then to 470 at the end of Edo period.

sen.j: こうした人数の拡大に対応するために、幕末には3組に分割され、黒鍬頭に任命された組頭（役高30俵1人扶持）が置かれた。
sen.e: In order to respond to such increase in the number, one unit of kurokuwa was divided into three groups at the end of Edo period, and kumikashira (a head of the group) (whose yakudaka (salary paid in accordance with the rank of one's post) was 30 bales of one-man rice stipend) who was appointed to kurokuwakashira was established.

In order to respond to such increase in the number, the kurokuwa (unit) was divided into three groups at the end of the Edo period and each of which was headed by kumikashira (a head of group) (whose yakudaka was 35 bales) appointed by Kurokuwakashira.
sen.cmt: 「黒鍬頭が組頭を任命していた」という意味です。不要な説明を削除しました。1人扶持は約5俵で「30俵1人扶持」は35俵のことです。ご参考http://www.viva-edo.com/houroku.html
sen.e: In order to respond to such increase in the number, the kurokuwa (unit) was divided into three groups at the end of the Edo period and each of which was headed by kumikashira (a head of group) (whose yakudaka was 35 bales) appointed by Kurokuwakashira.

sen.j: 幕末期には新設された役職の補充として見廻組や撒兵へ移動となり、また彰義隊にも多くが参加した。
sen.e: At the end of Edo period, kurokuwa (construction workers) was transferred to mimawarigumi (unit of patrolmen) or the withdrawal of troops in order to make up for a newly established post, and many of kurokuwa participated in Shogitai (group of former Tokugawa retainers opposed to the Meiji government who fought in the Battle of Ueno).

At the end of the Edo period, kurokuwa were transferred to mimawarigumi (unit of patrolmen) or foot soldier with Western-style training in order to make up the vacancy in the newly established posts, and many of kurokuwa joined Shogitai (group of former Tokugawa retainers opposed to the Meiji government who fought in the Battle of Ueno.)
sen.cmt: 撒兵は洋式の訓練を受けた歩兵のことです。ご参考http://dictionary.goo.ne.jp/leaf/jn2/88528/m0u/%E6%92%92%E5%85%B5/語句の用法を修正しました。
sen.e: At the end of the Edo period, kurokuwa were transferred to mimawarigumi (unit of patrolmen) or foot soldier with Western-style training in order to make up the vacancy in the newly established posts, and many of kurokuwa joined Shogitai (group of former Tokugawa retainers opposed to the Meiji government who fought in the Battle of Ueno.)

sen.j: なお、諸大名や民間にも黒鍬が存在した。
sen.e: In addition, kurokuwa (a construction worker) also existed among territorial lords and ordinary citizens.
In addition, kurokuwa (a construction worker) also existed among territorial lords and ordinary citizens.
In addition, kurokuwa (a construction worker) also existed among territorial lords and ordinary citizens.

sen.j: 特に民間においては、（道具の）黒鍬の産地の1つで近くに木曽川・長良川下流の輪中地帯を抱えていた尾張国知多郡の土工集団の「黒鍬」組は著名であり、各地に出稼ぎをして土木・治水工事・新田開発のための土地整備に参加した。
sen.e: The particularly renowned kurokuwa among ordinary citizens was a unit of 'kurokuwa,' a group of civil engineers in Chita County, Owari Province which was one of production areas of kurokuwa as a tool and which had a ring area downstream of Kiso-gawa River and Nagara-gawa River in the neighborhood, and such kurokuwa worked away from home to participate in the land development for civil engineering, flood prevention works and development of new field in various places.

The particularly renowned kurokuwa among ordinary citizens was a unit of 'kurokuwa,' a group of civil engineers in Chita County, Owari Province which was one of the production areas of kurokuwa (tool) and which held waju (settlement surrounded by dike) area in the downstream of Kiso-gawa River and Nagara-gawa River in the neighborhood, and such kurokuwa worked away from home to participate in the land development for civil engineering, flood prevention works and cultivation of new rice fields in various places.
sen.cmt: 輪中の訳を補いました。新田開発の訳を修正しました。
sen.e: The particularly renowned kurokuwa among ordinary citizens was a unit of 'kurokuwa,' a group of civil engineers in Chita County, Owari Province which was one of the production areas of kurokuwa (tool) and which held waju (settlement surrounded by dike) area in the downstream of Kiso-gawa River and Nagara-gawa River in the neighborhood, and such kurokuwa worked away from home to participate in the land development for civil engineering, flood prevention works and cultivation of new rice fields in various places.

sen.j: 劇画『カムイ外伝』では、主人公・カムイが追っ手から逃れるために、前述の民間の黒鍬に混じって身を潜めるシーンが登場する。
sen.e: "Kamui Gaiden" (Kamui the Ninja: Stories Other Than the Legend), gekiga (graphic novel), had a scene in which the main character, Kamui, holed up in the aforementioned civilian kurokuwa in order to escape from chasers.
sen.cmt: 『カムイ外伝』→"Kamui Gaiden" (Kamui the Ninja: Stories Other Than the Legend)[Wikipedia 「カムイ外伝」より]
sen.e: "Kamui Gaiden" (Kamui the Ninja: Stories Other Than the Legend), a gekiga (graphic novel), has a scene in which the main character, Kamui, holes up in the aforementioned civilian kurokuwa in order to escape from chasers.

sen.j: 劇画・時代劇『子連れ狼』に登場する黒鍬衆もこの黒鍬に由来している。
sen.e: Kurokuwashu (construction workers) appearing in "Lone Wolf and Cub," gekiga (graphic novel) and jidaigeki (historical play), originated from this kurokuwa.
Kurokuwashu (construction workers) in "Lone Wolf and Cub," a gekiga and also jidaigeki (historical play,) originated from this kurokuwa.
